title: I was banned, and now i'm restricted for 24 games?!
body:
This is incredible...

I'm just playing the game to the best of my abilities. 
I've been playing since season 2!

my main (IKuPAI) was banned for "unsportsmanlike conduct" - ie saying things people don't like... 
I may have cursed, but people are very rude and nasty... why do I have to mute them if I'm not offended? They should be muting me!




Anyways... so my 6 year account was permanently banned, and now i'm playing on a 4 year old account... I went 3/14 2x games in a row and I have no problem with my teammates reporting me, but to immediately punish me because of the number of people who report me is ridiculous. 

I'm quite sure my account will be banned yet again, and i can assure you this time account has used no expletives as I'm trying to behave to retain my account.

Honestly, go look up my main account (that was banned) and you'll see i'm a bronze lifer, and i've played for 6 years... I just can't climb, and i'm sorry that i'm bad.

Is it really okay to ban people for being bad?
or retaliating against toxic players with words?

they tell me to uninstall, I tell them to eat my sock... then everyone looks at my KDA and I'm getting reported!

great... while I was writing this I brought smite to top lane.

You'll never get a chat restriction for playing poorly -- a ban for intentionally feeding jumps right to a 14-day ban. As a result, this is likely a chat-related punishment.

That said, I'd recommend looking up some Tryndamere builds. Your builds on him aren't doing you any favors, as you overvalue Guinsoo's Rageblade on builds that don't have any real on-hit effects.

Some people have told me "if ur bad, don't play ranked"
but there's also that thing where "I'm more serious when I play ranked"

who wants to play with a bunch of obviously inting idiots?

anyways... I think build paths are more important than the build itself... Also power spikes are something that isn't exactly obvious either. They take time to learn!

> [{quoted}](name=Thr33Zer0Thr33,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=1gFdVTbA,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2019-04-26T15:39:38.422+0000)anyways... I think build paths are more important than the build itself... Also power spikes are something that isn't exactly obvious either. They take time to learn!

Build paths are part of the build, and both are important. In this case, it's crucial to realize that Tryndamere has no on-hit effects, and Guinsoo's is an item that scales heavily based on the strength of your on-hit effects due to the passive it has. Try replacing that item with an earlier Guardian Angel or a Death's Dance or a Stormrazor and you should find yourself having more success.

I use the Guinsoo for the on hits I get from tiamat and shiv though... it makes my wave clear something I'm not embarassed about...

Something that's funny to me is the "perfect cs"
high elo players can get 300 cs at 30 minutes... the people I play with MAX at 200 cs at 30 minutes. 300 cs is like a 50 minute game!

Yet, I'm the one who's bad. Obviously i'm in the elo i'm in because it's a reflection of how good I perform overall.

my individual game shouldn't reflect the entire account within a single post-game scoreboard.

If you were finding the Tryndamere is lacking waveclear with an AD Shiv build that includes Tiamat, the problem is likely something else in your gameplay. It's not worth sacrificing the strength you get from other itemization options to shore up a weakness that isn't even that much of a weakness in the big scheme of things. You lose too much compared to other items in your areas of strength, and you don't need waveclear that badly.
